Yes, in addition to EQ, here are some other tips for getting a clear and polished vocal sound:

1. Proper microphone placement: Make sure the vocalist is positioned correctly in front of the microphone, and experiment with different distances and angles until you find the sweet spot. 2. Use a pop filter: A pop filter can help prevent plosive sounds, such as "p" and "b" sounds, from hitting the microphone and causing unwanted distortion or harshness. 3. Recording environment: Make sure the recording environment is quiet and free from any unwanted noise or reflections, which can adversely affect the vocal recording quality. 4. Vocal tuning: If the vocalist is struggling with pitch or intonation, consider using pitch correction software such as Melodyne or Autotune to fine-tune the vocal performance. 5. Compression: Use gentle compression to even out the dynamics of the vocal performance and make it sound more polished and consistent. 6. Reverb and delay: Use reverb and delay effects to create a sense of depth and space around the vocals, but be careful not to overdo it and create a muddy or cluttered sound. Remember, vocals are often the focal point of a song, so it's important to spend the time and effort to get them sounding as good as possible. Be patient and use your ears to make sure you're getting the best possible sound.
